data.title: limit experiments to first time users; fixes #14009
data.body: See https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13825#issuecomment-254880953 for discussion.

data.title: Auto Add List Items
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.6.1 (1.6.1)
- OS Version: 10.12

_Feature Request_
When working in markdown files, it'd be great if after I start a list, each time I hit enter it would add another list item. That'd make working with Markdown much more efficient. 

Hitting enter twice would then break out of the list.

data.title: Run experiments only for first time users
data.body: We should run experiments only on first time for users so that our existing users are not impacted.

data.title: Intellisense not respecting jsdoc parameter type for typescript
data.body:
Intellisense works great for my postgress Pool type when explicitly declared:

![screen shot 2016-10-19 at 10 16 03 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/113954/19529521/15dfb24a-95e5-11e6-8c86-8a9f2e4c0e5a.png)

However when passed as a parameter to a function and described through a JSDoc parameter intellisense fails:

![screen shot 2016-10-19 at 10 14 57 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/113954/19529486/ec2f52ca-95e4-11e6-9748-f1ff9e3f6905.png)

- Extensions: Unity.unity-debug-1.0.1, benjaminromano.typings-installer-0.2.0, dbaeumer.vscode-eslint-1.0.7, dkundel.vscode-npm-source-0.0.3, joelday.docthis-0.3.4, mohsen1.prettify-json-0.0.3, ms-vscode.omnisharp-0.3.3, rafaelmaiolla.diff-0.0.1, stevencl.addDocComments-0.0.8, xabikos.JavaScriptSnippets-1.1.0, xabikos.ReactSnippets-1.1.1

data.title: Cursor goes back to starting location in "Default Settings" window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Version 1607 OS Build: 14393.321

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open "Default Settings" window by going to "File" menu > "Preferences" > "User Settings"
2. Drag the "settings.json" to the workspace where "Default Settings" window is present
3. Scroll down in "Default Settings" window
4. Go to another window
5. Come back to "Default Settings" window. We see the cursor at the starting location.
   Snapshot is attached as reference
   ![1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16834561/19529513/d4a55b4a-964d-11e6-9099-b7cd51ae6f2f.png)

data.title: Completion list disappears after dash character
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12

I'm working on [extension](https://github.com/ChristianKohler/NpmIntellisense) that autocompletes node package name in _import/require_ strings. There is a problem that inside package class that implements `CompletionItemProvider`, `provideCompletionItems` method doesn't fire when I type `-` inside _import/require_ string and this results in empty completion list. When you type next letter e.g. `d` it filters completion items JUST by this letter. It should still take the whole string into account.

This issue somehow references this [issue](https://github.com/ChristianKohler/NpmIntellisense/issues/10) from NpmIntellisense package.

**Steps to Reproduce:**

Install [NpmIntellisense](https://github.com/ChristianKohler/NpmIntellisense) package. Prepare project with `package.json` that have `react` and `react-dom` extension installed (and saved!!!).
1. Create some JS file.
2. Type `import React from 'react-'`
3. As soon as you type dash character `-`, completion list disappears.
4. After you type `import React from 'react-d'`, it filters text by letter `d` that is after dash character.

data.title: Prevent folders expanding when opening a file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Cmd + P, type filename
2. File is opened and the folder it exists in is expanded

Is there a way for it to only expand folders that the user manually expands. In a large project if I jump around files my folder tree gets expanded a lot and I then lose my focus of where I might have been working previously

data.title: Split editor icon
data.body:
I have concerns about the current horizontal split editor icon
1. Looks 3D
2. Looks much fuller / thicker compared to the vertical one
3. it should be like the vertical one rotated by 90 degrees (with the title staying on top)

FYI @bpasero

data.title: 'Toggle editor layout' bad naming
data.body:
F1 > search for 'horizontal' or 'vertical'
Toggle editor layout does not contain either 'horizontal' or 'vertical' in the name. Optimally it should change title dimanically based on the layout. However since that is unsupported  it should at least have a name which contains both of these key words which the users will search for imho

'Toggle Vertical/Horizontal Layout' is an idea

data.title: Replace In Files recompares replaced matches and represents them AGAIN to the user, which is confusing
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: mac osx sierra

Steps to Reproduce:
1 Create and save several files with the string Thoma
2 Edit > Replace in Files 
    Find: Thoma
    Replace: Thomas
    You now see the matches for "Thoma" -> "Thomas"
3. Select one match and click the 'replace' icon
    The match disappears and immediately reappears with a match "Thomas" -> "Thomass"

Expected behaviour: Once the match has been replaced, it SHOULD be ignored until the user selects refresh or makes a new search

data.title: Jump along indent
data.body:
I'd like to be able to quickly jump along the same indentation, as in: https://packagecontrol.io/packages/Jump%20Along%20Indent

I also like keybindings in this extension, very useful.
It conflicts with current move lines up/down keybindings (alt + up/down) but that functionality could be improved: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/12718#issuecomment-254792297

data.body:

data.title: HTML files and format code with tabs
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a HTML file and define this `.vscode/settings.json`

`{
  "editor.tabSize": 2,
  "editor.insertSpaces": true,
  "editor.renderWhitespace": "all"
}`
1. Auto format ALWAYS changes indentation to Tabs, even when choosing to spaces.

data.title: Add support for API that is considered experimental
data.body: We don't want to break our API but we still want to explore new areas. For that we need the concept of experimental API to which extension writers have to explicit opt-in to be aware of the consequences.

data.title: [JS] IntelliSense doesn't detect function properties defined outside an object literal initialisation
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Fedora 21

If an object is initialised using the literal notation (object = {}) and a function property is added to the object outside the initialisation, IntelliSense doesn't detect it for code completion.

Steps to Reproduce:
![intellisense example](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5260674/19513070/8b847ade-95e6-11e6-8d70-c3d724f6ff31.png)

data.title: Open Readme when Extension Install is Clicked
data.body:
- VSCode Version: All
- OS Version: All

I think we should open the readme automatically if a user clicks install on an extension.  Today we install and prompt to re-start and as a result it's very easy to miss the readme.

Is there a reason we don't do that?  It was brought up in a discussion for the Go extension.

data.title: Leading and trailing spaces of property names are not displayed correctly
data.body:
- leading spaces are not shown at all
- trailing spaces are replaced by the same amount of whitespace

![2016-10-19_11-05-24](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/19512396/f54aef52-95eb-11e6-987d-eb0d4b756b77.png)

If the font is a is monospaced I would expect that a single space has the same width as any visible character and that all property names resemble what I see in the source.

data.title: Show error in Explorer tree file icon
data.body:
This is a request for visual feedback of errors.

If I am working on a file and make a change that causes errors in other files I would like to be able to glance over to the Explorer tree and see where the errors are.

Possibly add a red x (or circle) on the file (or parent folder) icon that has the error.

I know I can have a look at "Problems" - but that involves looking down and clicking. 
I use "Problems" if there is a large amount of issues or I want to see details.

I'm currently using VSCode 1.6.1.

data.title: Smarter way to add (and autoclose) brackets

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Hi,

Here’s a feature request for a thing I miss from SublimeText: opening a {  / [ and have it automatically closed **after** an indented part of code.

Here’s the behavior that I expect: 
![](http://files.italic.fr/screencast_2016-10-19_10-17-19.gif)

And what we got in VSC at the moment: 
![](http://files.italic.fr/screencast_2016-10-19_10-23-11.gif) 

Of course, this should obviously work with a bigger part of code, as long as it's indented, and for any language.

Many thanks!
